name: Kalam
description: Kalam is a scenic valley located in the upper reaches of Swat District. Surrounded by lush forests, rivers and mountains.
roadCondition: Mountain roads, some parts are rough; may face seasonal closures
safetyNotes: Carry power bank; avoid traveling in monsoon at night; landslides possible

name: Ushu Forest
description: A dense alpine forest near Kalam, known for its tall cedar and pine trees, offering fresh air and breathtaking landscapes.
roadCondition: Rough mountain road; requires jeep after Kalam
safetyNotes: Travel in daylight; roads can be slippery during rain.

name: Mahodand Lake
description: A glacial alpine lake located about 35 km from Kalam, surrounded by snow-capped peaks, lush meadows, and thick forests.
entryFeePermits: No entry fee; Jeep rent required
roadCondition: Rough track; only jeeps can reach the lake
safetyNotes: Cold even in summer; avoid during monsoon due to flooding.

name: Gabral Valley
description: A beautiful valley near Kalam, famous for rivers, green meadows, and trout fishing opportunities.
roadCondition: Gravel and rough roads; jeep recommended.
safetyNotes: Nights are cold; carry warm clothes.

name: Utror Valley
description: A serene valley near Kalam, surrounded by glaciers, waterfalls, and alpine meadows. Utror is a gateway to Gabral and Kandol Lake.
safetyNotes: Cold even in summer; snow blocks road in winter.

name: Bahrain
description: A bustling riverside town in Swat, known as a tourist stopover with vibrant bazaars, riverside hotels, and local handicrafts.
safetyNotes: Town gets crowded in summer; book hotels early.

name: Matiltan Valley
description: A scenic valley near Kalam, surrounded by glaciers, waterfalls, and snow-covered peaks. Known as a base for trekking.
roadCondition: Unpaved jeep road; rough in rain
safetyNotes: Take warm clothes; trekking requires stamina.

name: Madyan
description: A small town on the banks of River Swat, famous for trout fish, bazaars, and as a popular stopover for tourists on way to Kalam.
safetyNotes: Gets crowded in peak summer.

name: Miandam
description: A hill station with pleasant weather, pine forests, and streams, offering peaceful surroundings for relaxation and hiking.
safetyNotes: Cool weather; carry light jackets in summer.

name: Malam Jabba
description: The only ski resort in Pakistan, offering skiing, chair lifts, hiking trails, and panoramic views of the Hindu Kush range.
bestTimeToVisit: December - March (for skiing), April - October (for hiking)
safetyNotes: Snow chains required in peak winter; book hotels in advance during ski season.

name: Jarogo Waterfall
description: Jarogo Waterfall, also called 'Niagra Falls of Pakistan', is one of the highest waterfalls in Swat hidden within dense forests and mountains.
roadCondition: Narrow hilly road, final hike required
safetyNotes: Wear comfortable shoes; avoid monsoon due to slippery rocks.

name: Marghazar White Palace
description: Built in 1940 by the first Wali of Swat, the White Palace in Marghazar is made of white marble and is now a heritage hotel and tourist attraction.
safetyNotes: Busy in tourist season; book hotels early.

name: Shahi Bagh Kalam
description: A lush green meadow surrounded by snow-clad peaks near Kalam, known for its picnic spots and serene environment.
safetyNotes: Cold at night; camping gear recommended.

name: Falak Sar Peak
description: Falak Sar is the highest peak of Swat Valley, often called 'Queen of Swat Peaks', reaching an altitude of 5,918 meters. It is a challenging trekking and climbing destination.
entryFeePermits: Permit may be required for climbing
safetyNotes: High altitude; proper gear required.

name: Desaan Meadows
description: A hidden alpine meadow near Kalam, offering spectacular views of snow-capped peaks, fresh streams, and lush greenery.
safetyNotes: Remote area; camping gear and guide required.

name: Tirat Valley
description: A lush valley in Swat with fertile fields, streams, and villages, offering cultural experiences and natural beauty.
safetyNotes: Easy access but basic facilities only.

name: Saidu Sharif Museum
description: The Saidu Sharif Museum showcases the history, Gandhara art, and Buddhist heritage of Swat Valley. It houses relics, sculptures, and ancient manuscripts.
safetyNotes: Safe; museum timings apply

name: Akhund Darweza Shrine
description: A shrine of the revered Sufi saint Akhund Darweza Baba, visited by devotees for spiritual blessings and cultural significance.
safetyNotes: Respect cultural and religious practices.

name: Shanku Waterfall
description: A lesser-known but stunning waterfall in the Shanku area of Swat, surrounded by greenery and rocky landscapes.
safetyNotes: Slippery rocks near waterfall; caution required.

name: Lalku Valley
description: A serene valley near Kalam surrounded by alpine forests, streams, and grazing pastures. Less crowded and perfect for trekkers.
safetyNotes: Cold at night; carry warm clothes.

name: Mankial Valley
description: A remote but enchanting valley in Swat, famous for its snow-covered peaks, alpine meadows, and crystal streams.
safetyNotes: Remote and less facilities; guide recommended.

name: Landakai
description: Landakai is the gateway to Swat Valley, known for its historical importance during the Gandhara civilization and its scenic location.
safetyNotes: Busy during tourist season

name: Tirat Baba Shrine
description: A spiritual shrine dedicated to the saint known as Tirat Baba, visited by locals for religious and cultural gatherings.
safetyNotes: Respect religious traditions

name: Swat Valley
description: Swat Valley is known as the 'Switzerland of the East'. Famous for its lush green valleys, snow-capped mountains, rivers, waterfalls, and rich cultural heritage.
roadCondition: Generally good, mountain roads to upper valleys may be rough
safetyNotes: Avoid late-night travel; monsoon season may cause landslides

name: Gabbin Jaba
description: Gabbin Jaba is a beautiful hilltop meadow located in Swat Valley. Known for its lush green pastures, panoramic mountain views, cool climate, and serene environment. It is a popular spot for camping, hiking, and nature photography.
roadCondition: Rough mountain road, accessible by jeep/SUV
safetyNotes: Travel in daytime only; road becomes slippery during rain. Not recommended for small cars.

name: Naran
description: Naran is famous for its alpine lakes (Saif-ul-Mulook), meadows, and mountain views.
roadCondition: Mountain roads, may be closed in winter or due to landslides
safetyNotes: Travel in daytime; some remote areas may have weak signal; carry cash

name: Kaghan Valley
description: Kaghan Valley is a picturesque valley famous for its alpine meadows, crystal lakes, lush forests, and snow-covered peaks.
roadCondition: Mountain roads, prone to landslides in monsoon
safetyNotes: Travel with warm clothes; avoid night driving

name: Saif-ul-Malook Lake
description: A legendary alpine lake surrounded by snow-covered peaks, famous for its fairytale folklore and breathtaking reflections.
roadCondition: Requires jeep, steep and rocky road
safetyNotes: Carry warm clothes, road is rough, avoid late evening trips

name: Lulusar Lake
description: The largest natural lake in Kaghan Valley, source of Kunhar River, surrounded by snowcapped peaks.
restaurantsNearby: No major restaurants, only small tea stalls
roadCondition: Accessible via Naran-Babusar road, seasonal closures due to snow
safetyNotes: High altitude, limited facilities, travel prepared

name: Dudipatsar Lake
description: Known as the 'Queen of Lakes', Dudipatsar is a hidden alpine lake surrounded by snowcapped mountains.
bestVehicleTo: 4x4 Jeep to Mulla ki Basti + Trekking
restaurantsNearby: None at lake, only tea stalls at base camp
entryFeePermits: Requires trekking permit in some cases
safetyNotes: Physically demanding trek, carry camping gear

name: Ansoo Lake
description: A tear-shaped alpine lake near Malika Parbat, considered one of the most beautiful hidden lakes of Pakistan.
safetyNotes: Demanding trek, high altitude, carry warm clothes

name: Babusar Top
description: The highest point of the Kaghan Valley road, offering breathtaking views and connecting Kaghan with Gilgit-Baltistan.
safetyNotes: Snowfall in winter closes the pass; drive carefully

name: Shogran
description: A lush green plateau at the height of 7,749 ft, popular for its panoramic views and cool climate.
safetyNotes: Jeep recommended, road is narrow

name: Siri Paye Meadows
description: Famous alpine meadows near Shogran, known for wildflowers and stunning views of Makra Peak.
safetyNotes: Not suitable for cars, only jeeps

name: Balakot
description: Balakot is the gateway to Kaghan Valley, located on the banks of Kunhar River, known for its bazaars and historical significance.
safetyNotes: Can get crowded in tourist season

name: Kunhar River
description: The lifeline of Kaghan Valley, Kunhar River flows from Lulusar Lake to Balakot, famous for trout fishing and riverside camping.
hotelsNearby: Riverside Hotels in Kaghan and Balakot
safetyNotes: River current is strong, avoid swimming

name: Khanian
description: A peaceful village along Kunhar River, surrounded by forests and mountains, known for its natural charm.
safetyNotes: Peaceful, but limited facilities

name: Kiwai Waterfall
description: A beautiful roadside waterfall near Kiwai, often the starting point for Shogran jeep track.
safetyNotes: Slippery rocks near waterfall

name: Nori Top
description: A scenic mountain pass connecting Kaghan Valley with Neelum Valley (Azad Kashmir).
safetyNotes: Remote, carry essentials

name: Battakundi
description: A small picturesque village on the way to Babusar Top, surrounded by mountains and lush meadows.
safetyNotes: Weather changes quickly, carry warm clothes

name: Kaghan Forest
description: Dense coniferous forest near Kaghan town, offering scenic hiking trails and wildlife.
safetyNotes: Travel in groups, avoid late evening

name: Naran Bazaar
description: Main marketplace of Naran town, filled with restaurants, shops, handicrafts, and tourist facilities.
safetyNotes: Crowded in summer

name: Kaghan Bazaar
description: The central marketplace of Kaghan town, offering handicrafts, food, and essential supplies for travelers.
safetyNotes: Busy during tourist season

name: Chitral Town
description: Chitral Town is the main hub of the Chitral District, known for its rich culture, hospitality, and breathtaking views of the Hindu Kush mountains.
roadCondition: Mostly paved; narrow in sections near Lowari Tunnel
safetyNotes: Lowari Tunnel may close during heavy snow; carry warm clothing.

name: Chitral Fort
description: Chitral Fort, also known as Mehtars Fort, was built in the 18th century and remains the residence of the Mehtar of Chitral. It overlooks the Chitral River and reflects the heritage of the region.
entryFeePermits: May require local permission for photography
safetyNotes: Respect local customs near the fort compound.

name: Shahi Masjid Chitral
description: Shahi Masjid Chitral is a beautiful white marble mosque built by Shuja-ul-Mulk in 1924, located near Chitral Fort. It is one of the most iconic landmarks in Chitral.
safetyNotes: Dress modestly and avoid photography during prayer times.

name: Kalash Valleys (Bumburet, Rumbur, Birir)
description: The Kalash Valleys are home to the Kalash people, known for their unique culture, language, and colorful festivals. The valleys include Bumburet, Rumbur, and Birir.
requiredDocuments: Foreigners must register at Chitral Police
safetyNotes: Avoid travel during heavy rain; respect local traditions.

name: Garam Chashma
description: Garam Chashma, meaning Hot Spring, is famous for its naturally heated sulfur springs and stunning mountain surroundings, believed to have healing properties.
safetyNotes: Drive carefully; carry warm clothing.

name: Shandur Pass
description: Known as the Roof of the World, Shandur Pass connects Chitral and Gilgit. Its famous for the annual Shandur Polo Festival and breathtaking high-altitude meadows.
requiredDocuments: Travel permit for foreigners (from DC Office Chitral)
entryFeePermits: May require NOC during festival season
safetyNotes: Carry oxygen and warm gear; avoid visiting during snowfall.

name: Shandur Lake
description: Located beside the famous Shandur Polo Ground, Shandur Lake is a crystal-clear alpine lake surrounded by rolling green meadows and snow-capped peaks.
safetyNotes: Cold winds; camping gear and warm clothes essential.

name: Tirich Mir Peak
description: Tirich Mir is the highest peak of the Hindu Kush range and the highest mountain in Pakistan outside the Karakoram. It dominates the skyline north of Chitral Town.
safetyNotes: Extreme altitude; suitable only for trained trekkers.

name: Ayun Valley
description: Ayun Valley is a lush green valley located 12 km south of Chitral, offering serene views of the river and mountains and serving as the gateway to the Kalash Valleys.
roadCondition: Good condition; paved till valley center
safetyNotes: Avoid late-night driving due to mountain turns.

name: Madaklasht Ski Resort
description: Madaklasht is a hidden gem in the Hindu Kush, known for its snow-covered slopes and emerging as Pakistans next big winter sports destination.
safetyNotes: Use 4x4 vehicle; snow chains recommended.

name: Booni Gol National Park
description: Booni Gol National Park is a newly established protected area in Upper Chitral, known for its high-altitude meadows, snow leopards, and ibex herds. It offers pristine wilderness for trekkers and nature enthusiasts.
safetyNotes: Cold nights; carry tents and food supplies.

name: Rosh Gol Valley
description: Rosh Gol Valley is a serene hidden valley near Mastuj, known for its alpine forests, crystal streams, and the friendly Wakhi-speaking community.
safetyNotes: Limited accommodation; arrange homestay in advance.

name: Drosh Valley
description: Drosh Valley lies along the Chitral River, south of Chitral Town. Its known for orchards, terraced fields, and as a historical trade route to Afghanistan.
roadCondition: Paved road with scenic mountain turns
safetyNotes: Moderate traffic; best visited during daylight.

name: Baroghil Valley
description: Baroghil Valley is one of Pakistans most remote and spectacular regions, located near the Afghan border. Its home to the Wakhi people and gateway to Karambar Lake.
entryFeePermits: NOC from DC Office Chitral required
roadCondition: Gravel and dirt tracks; very remote
safetyNotes: Only for experienced trekkers; bring satellite communication.

name: Karambar Lake
description: Karambar Lake, the second-highest alpine lake in Pakistan, sits between Chitral and Gilgit-Baltistan at 4,272 meters. Its turquoise waters and reflection of mountains make it a dream trekking destination.
roadCondition: Trekking route; no vehicle access beyond Ishkarwaz
safetyNotes: Extreme cold; carry tents, food, and water purification tablets.

name: Darkot Pass
description: Darkot Pass connects Baroghil Valley (Chitral) to Yasin Valley (Gilgit-Baltistan). Its a legendary trekking route through glaciers and alpine meadows.
safetyNotes: Only for skilled trekkers; high altitude hazards.

name: Mastuj Fort
description: Mastuj Fort is an ancient stronghold guarding the northern approach to Chitral. It offers historical charm, panoramic views, and access to the Upper Chitral valleys.
safetyNotes: Stable area; good for families and groups.

name: Kumrat Valley
description: Kumrat Valley is one of the most scenic valleys in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, known for its pine forests, Panjkora River, and snow-capped mountains.
roadCondition: Unpaved jeep track; rough patches near forest area
safetyNotes: Avoid traveling after sunset; landslides possible during rains

name: Jahaz Banda Meadows
description: Jahaz Banda is a beautiful alpine meadow in the upper reaches of Kumrat Valley, famous for lush greenery, waterfalls, and trekking trails.
roadCondition: Jeep track, rough in upper sections
safetyNotes: Carry warm clothes; weather changes rapidly

name: Katora Lake
description: Katora Lake is a high-altitude glacial lake located above Jahaz Banda in Kumrat Valley, known for its bowl-like shape and turquoise water.
roadCondition: Hiking trail from Jahaz Banda (moderate to tough)
safetyNotes: Carry camping gear; lake remains frozen till June

name: Do Kala Chashma
description: Do Kala Chashma is a twin spring located near Jahaz Banda in Upper Dir. Its crystal-clear waters and serene environment make it a hidden gem for trekkers.
roadCondition: Rough jeep track followed by short hike
safetyNotes: Be cautious around slippery rocks near the springs

name: Lamchar Valley
description: Lamchar Valley is a lush green valley in Upper Dir, surrounded by pine forests and traditional villages offering an authentic cultural experience.
roadCondition: Mostly paved, some rough mountain paths
safetyNotes: Drive carefully; limited fuel stations nearby

name: Sheringal Valley
description: Sheringal is a peaceful valley and administrative hub of Dir Kohistan, known for its university campus, riverside scenery, and friendly locals.
safetyNotes: Safe for families and solo travelers

name: Ranisar Lake
description: Ranisar Lake is a small alpine lake located in the upper reaches of Dir Valley. Its famous for its reflection of surrounding snowy peaks.
roadCondition: Hiking path; jeep track till base camp
safetyNotes: Cold even in summer; carry warm clothes

name: Gwaldai Valley
description: Gwaldai Valley is a peaceful and lesser-known destination near Dir, offering panoramic views, lush meadows, and streams flowing through pine forests.
safetyNotes: Avoid heavy rain travel due to slippery slopes

name: Barikot Dir
description: Barikot is a historic town in Dir known for its scenic location, local markets, and access to nearby natural attractions in Upper Dir.
safetyNotes: Safe and accessible year-round

name: Thal Valley
description: Thal Valley serves as the gateway to Kumrat and other scenic valleys. It is surrounded by pine forests and traversed by the Panjkora River.
roadCondition: Good road till Thal; jeep track beyond
safetyNotes: Avoid monsoon season; river floods occasionally

name: Kalkot Valley
description: Kalkot Valley is a peaceful and lush green valley located in Upper Dir District. Known for its fresh streams, scenic beauty, and traditional wooden houses.
roadCondition: Mostly paved, rough patches near upper regions
safetyNotes: Avoid travel in heavy rain due to possible landslides.

name: Bin Shahi Valley
description: Bin Shahi Valley is a breathtaking valley near the Afghan border, famous for its alpine meadows, pine forests, and snow-capped peaks.
roadCondition: Partially paved; off-road near upper sections.
safetyNotes: Travel with local guide; avoid monsoon season.

name: Laram Top
description: Laram Top is a stunning viewpoint located near Timergara in Lower Dir. It offers panoramic views of surrounding valleys and snow-clad peaks.
roadCondition: Good paved road till the top.
safetyNotes: Carry light jackets; windy during evenings.

name: Panjkora River
description: Panjkora River flows through Dir District, adding life to the valleys of Kumrat, Thal, and Dir. Known for its clear water, trout fishing, and riverside beauty.
roadCondition: Good in lower areas, rough near upper regions.
safetyNotes: Exercise caution near riverbanks; avoid swimming in strong currents.

name: Nathia Gali
description: Nathia Gali is one of the most famous hill stations in Pakistan, located between Abbottabad and Murree. Surrounded by pine forests, it offers cool weather, hiking trails, and colonial-style architecture.
safetyNotes: Drive carefully during fog; roads can be slippery in rain.

name: Dunga Gali
description: Dunga Gali is a serene hill spot famous for its colonial buildings and access to the Dunga Gali Pipeline Track that leads to Ayubia. Its quieter than Nathia Gali, ideal for peaceful retreats.
safetyNotes: Carry warm clothes; fog common in evenings.

name: Changla Gali
description: Changla Gali is a quiet and lush green hill station on the Murree-Nathia Gali road, known for its cool climate and forest trails. Its ideal for tourists seeking calm and scenic beauty.
roadCondition: Excellent; part of Murree-Nathia Gali highway.
safetyNotes: Occasional fog and narrow roads; drive carefully.

name: Bara Gali
description: Bara Gali is a peaceful hill town located between Abbottabad and Murree, home to University of Peshawars summer campus and surrounded by thick pine forests.
safetyNotes: Cool weather year-round; foggy in evenings.

name: Kalabagh Gali
description: Kalabagh Gali is a lesser-known yet stunning spot in the Galiyat region. Nestled between Dunga Gali and Nathia Gali, it offers mesmerizing mountain views, cool weather, and peaceful surroundings.
safetyNotes: Fog and low visibility possible in evening hours.

name: Mukshpuri Top
description: Mukshpuri Top is the second highest peak in Galiyat, offering panoramic views of the Kashmir Valley, snow-covered peaks, and surrounding forests. Its one of Pakistans most scenic and accessible hiking trails.
entryFeePermits: Entry ticket required for Ayubia National Park trails
roadCondition: Paved road till Dunga Gali; hiking trail ahead.
safetyNotes: Carry water, hiking shoes, and light jacket.

name: Miranjani Top
description: Miranjani is the highest peak in Galiyat, offering spectacular views of the Himalayan range and Abbottabad valley. The trek starts near Nathia Gali and takes 2-3 hours to reach the top.
entryFeePermits: Small entry ticket required for forest area
roadCondition: Good road till base, hiking trail to summit.
safetyNotes: Start early morning; carry water and snacks.

name: Ayubia National Park
description: Ayubia National Park is a protected forest area known for its diverse wildlife, dense pine forests, and scenic hiking trails. Its home to Mukshpuri Top, Miranjani Peak, and the famous Dunga Gali Pipeline Track.
safetyNotes: Respect wildlife; avoid littering inside park.

name: Dunga Gali Pipeline Track
description: The Dunga Gali Pipeline Track is a 4-km scenic walkway connecting Dunga Gali to Ayubia. Its one of Pakistans most famous walking trails, offering forest views, birdwatching, and calm mountain air.
entryFeePermits: Small entry fee near Ayubia gate
roadCondition: Excellent paved road till trail start.
safetyNotes: Wear walking shoes; avoid during heavy rain.

name: Ilyasi Masjid Abbottabad
description: Ilyasi Masjid is the oldest and most famous mosque in Abbottabad, known for its white marble structure and natural spring flowing beneath it. It's a beautiful example of Islamic architecture and a popular local landmark.
roadCondition: Good paved road from Abbottabad city.
safetyNotes: Respect prayer times and dress modestly.

name: Thandiani Hill Station
description: Thandiani, meaning 'very cold place', is a serene hill station near Abbottabad, offering breathtaking views of the snow-capped Pir Panjal range and pine forests. Its an ideal getaway for nature lovers.
safetyNotes: Avoid travel in heavy rain or snow.

name: Harnoi Picnic Point
description: Harnoi is a popular picnic and family recreation point located along the Harnoi River near Abbottabad. It features natural streams, greenery, and small amusement rides for children.
roadCondition: Good paved road from Abbottabad city.
safetyNotes: Avoid swimming in strong river current.

name: Sherwan Hills Abbottabad
description: Sherwan Hills are located west of Abbottabad, offering lush green trails, panoramic valley views, and calm weather. It's a hidden gem for hikers and photographers.
safetyNotes: Best visited in daylight; watch for wildlife.

name: Ayubia Chairlift
description: Ayubia Chairlift is one of the most popular attractions in Galiyat. It connects Ayubia with Mushkpuri and offers breathtaking aerial views of pine forests and hills.
safetyNotes: Follow safety instructions during ride.

name: Ayubia Zoo
description: Ayubia Zoo is a small but charming wildlife park located near Ayubia Chairlift. It houses various species of local animals and birds amidst a beautiful forested environment.
safetyNotes: Do not feed animals; keep children supervised.

name: Umbrella Waterfall
description: Umbrella Waterfall is a mesmerizing natural cascade near Poona village, Haripur. Known for its unique umbrella-shaped rock formation and crystal-clear water, it requires a short but adventurous hike from the main road near Sajikot.
entryFeePermits: No entry fee; parking charges apply
roadCondition: Partly paved, narrow mountain road; 3040 min trek to waterfall
safetyNotes: Slippery rocks; avoid visiting during heavy rain or late evening

name: Sajikot Waterfall
description: Sajikot Waterfall is a famous multi-tiered waterfall in Abbottabad District, featuring turquoise pools surrounded by mountains. It's one of the most accessible waterfalls in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and a favorite picnic spot.
roadCondition: Mostly paved with steep curves; easily accessible by car
safetyNotes: Avoid swimming in deep pools; slippery rocks in monsoon season

name: Noori Waterfall
description: Noori Waterfall is a hidden gem located in Tial village of Haripur District. Its emerald-green water and tranquil surroundings make it a popular weekend destination among nature lovers.
roadCondition: Rough mountain path in last 2 km; trekking required
safetyNotes: Steep rocks; avoid visiting during heavy rainfall

name: Chajian Waterfall
description: Chajian Waterfall, also spelled Chhajjian, is one of the tallest waterfalls in Pakistan. Surrounded by lush green hills, it stands over 400 feet high and offers a serene escape near Haripur city.
roadCondition: Partly paved road with short trek to waterfall base
safetyNotes: Caution advised during rainy season; rocks can be slippery

name: Kundol Lake
description: Kundol Lake is a beautiful alpine lake located in Utror Valley, Swat. Surrounded by snow-capped peaks and pine forests, it's accessible after a scenic jeep ride and a 2-hour hike from Ladu Valley.
roadCondition: Jeep track till Ladu Valley; moderate trek to the lake
safetyNotes: Avoid during winter; snow covers the trail

name: Spin Khwar Lake
description: Spin Khwar Lake, also known as the White Stream Lake, is a hidden gem in the Swat Valley located near Ushu and Gabral. It is surrounded by alpine meadows and snow-capped mountains, accessible via a moderate jeep and trekking route.
roadCondition: Off-road after Gabral; requires jeep and short hike
safetyNotes: Carry camping gear; weather changes quickly in high altitudes

name: Daral Lake
description: Daral Lake is an alpine lake near Bahrain in the Swat Valley. Known for its turquoise water and surrounding peaks, it is reached after a scenic trek through Daral Meadows.
roadCondition: Rough jeep track followed by hiking trail
safetyNotes: Avoid visiting in monsoon due to landslides

name: Saidgai Lake
description: Saidgai Lake lies at the boundary of Upper Dir and Swat districts. It is one of the most beautiful and less explored lakes in northern Pakistan, surrounded by wildflowers and alpine terrain.
roadCondition: Jeep track and 3-hour trek from Ushirai Dara
safetyNotes: Travel in groups; cold winds even in summer

name: Pari Lake
description: Pari Lake, also known as Fairy Lake, is located above Ushu in the upper Swat Valley. The lake is famous for its deep blue color and legends of fairies said to inhabit the area.
safetyNotes: Avoid trekking alone; snow may block route early in season

name: Shahi Lake
description: Shahi Lake, also known as Lake Sakhra, is a hidden alpine lake near Lamoti village in Upper Dir. It is surrounded by dramatic mountain ranges and green meadows, making it ideal for nature lovers.
roadCondition: Jeep-accessible dirt track followed by hike
safetyNotes: Carry food supplies; limited mobile network

name: Jabba Waterfall
description: Jabba Waterfall is a breathtaking natural waterfall located near Oghi in the Mansehra District. Surrounded by lush green hills, it is a peaceful spot for day trips and picnics.
safetyNotes: Be cautious near slippery rocks during rainy season

name: Mahaban Waterfall
description: Mahaban Waterfall, located in the Mahaban Hills of Buner District, is an emerging tourist destination known for its serene surroundings, crystal-clear waters, and panoramic views of the valley.
roadCondition: Good condition; minor rough patches near site
safetyNotes: Avoid visiting during heavy rains due to flash flood risk

name: Peshawar Museum
description: Peshawar Museum is one of the most renowned museums in South Asia, housing a rich collection of Gandhara art, Buddhist relics, coins, manuscripts, and artifacts from the Mughal and Kushan periods.
safetyNotes: Crowded during weekends; maintain respectful behavior in heritage area

name: Bala Hisar Fort
description: Bala Hisar Fort, meaning 'High Fort', is one of the most iconic landmarks of Peshawar. It was built in the 16th century and served as a royal residence and defense fort for centuries.
safetyNotes: Photography may be restricted near military zones

name: Islamia College Peshawar
description: Islamia College is a historic educational institution founded in 1913. It is a masterpiece of Mughal Revival architecture and played a pivotal role in the Pakistan Movement.
entryFeePermits: Permission required for photography inside campus
safetyNotes: Respect academic environment and cultural norms

name: Qissa Khwani Bazaar
description: Qissa Khwani Bazaar, also known as 'Storytellers Market', is one of the oldest marketplaces in South Asia. It was a hub for merchants and travelers who shared tales from the Silk Road era.
safetyNotes: Keep valuables secure; crowded on weekends

name: Sethi House
description: Sethi House is a 19th-century mansion in the historic Mohallah Sethian, famous for its intricate woodwork, jharokas, and Kashmiri-style architecture reflecting the opulent merchant era of old Peshawar.
safetyNotes: Wear modest clothing; respect cultural sites

name: Gor Khatri
description: Gor Khatri is an archaeological complex on a hilltop in Peshawar, believed to be the site of ancient Pushkalavati. Excavations have revealed layers of history from the Kushan, Mughal, and Sikh eras.
safetyNotes: Some areas under excavation  restricted zones marked

name: Mahabat Khan Mosque
description: Mahabat Khan Mosque, built in 1630 during the Mughal era, is a striking architectural masterpiece featuring intricate frescoes, large domes, and a grand prayer hall. It is one of the most visited historical mosques in Peshawar.
safetyNotes: Respect mosque rules; remove shoes inside prayer hall

name: Khyber Pass
description: Khyber Pass is a historic mountain pass connecting Pakistan and Afghanistan. Famous for its strategic importance, it has been used for centuries by traders, invaders, and travelers.
safetyNotes: Check security advisories; avoid traveling alone near border

name: Jamrud Fort
description: Jamrud Fort, located at the entrance of the Khyber Pass, was built in 1836 by the Sikh Empire. It holds historical significance as a frontier defense post and is a major tourist attraction.
safetyNotes: Respect security personnel; avoid photography near checkpoints

name: Michni Checkpost (Torkham)
description: Michni Checkpost is a border security post at Torkham, marking the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. It is an important trade and travel point on the historic Khyber Pass route.
entryFeePermits: Restricted area; entry may require permission
safetyNotes: Travel only with permission; follow all security protocols

name: Khyber Railway Track
description: Khyber Railway Track, built during the British era, connects Peshawar to Landi Kotal. The route is scenic, passing through hills and tunnels, and is part of Pakistan's historic railway heritage.
safetyNotes: Travel only during daytime; restricted zones near stations

name: Rahman Baba Shrine
description: Rahman Baba Shrine is dedicated to the famous Pashto Sufi poet, Rahman Baba. It is a spiritual and cultural landmark visited by devotees and tourists for its serene environment and poetry inspiration.
safetyNotes: Respect shrine etiquette; photography inside shrine may be restricted

name: Takht-i-Bahi
description: Takht-i-Bahi is an ancient Buddhist monastic complex dating from the 1st century CE, located in Mardan District. It is one of the best preserved Buddhist monasteries in the Gandhara region and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
busStationsFromPeshawar: Peshawar Bus Terminals via Mardan route
entryFeePermits: Entry fee for visitors (local & foreign)  check at gate
roadCondition: Good paved road up to site; short uphill walk
safetyNotes: Stay on marked paths; avoid climbing unstable walls

name: Jamal Garhi Buddhist Ruins
description: Jamal Garhi is an ancient Buddhist monastery complex dating from the 1st to 5th centuries AD. It contains stupas, monastic quarters and is one of the Gandharan civilizations archaeological sites. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
entryFeePermits: Entry fee (local and foreign) may apply
roadCondition: Paved road; short uphill path to ruins
safetyNotes: Fragile structures; avoid stray climbing

name: Shahbaz Garhi Rock Edicts
description: Shahbaz Garhi is known for its rock edicts of Ashoka (3rd century BCE), carved on rocks along the Haro River. It is one of the earliest examples of writing in the region.
roadCondition: Approachable by paved road; site is roadside
safetyNotes: Avoid touching inscriptions; weathering fragile

name: Hund Ruins
description: Hund was the ancient capital of the Hindu Shahi dynasty and later an important Gandharan site. The ruins include graves, old city walls, and historical remains.
safetyNotes: Watch for unstable ruins; visit during daylight

name: Rani Gatt Ruins
description: Rani Gatt is an ancient Buddhist archaeological site located in Buner District. It features the ruins of stupas, monasteries, and sculptures dating back to the 2nd century BCE, reflecting the Gandhara civilization.
roadCondition: Mostly paved; final stretch is hilly and rough
safetyNotes: Avoid visiting after sunset; carry drinking water.

name: Nowshera Fort
description: Nowshera Fort, also known as Fort Jehangira, is a British-era fort established in the 19th century. It served as a key defensive structure during colonial times near the Kabul River.
safetyNotes: Avoid visiting restricted military sections.

name: Chakdara Fort
description: Chakdara Fort, situated near the Swat River, is a strategic British-era fort built in 1895. It guarded the Malakand Pass and provides scenic views of the valley.
safetyNotes: Drive carefully around river bends; fort under army supervision.

name: Malakand Fort
description: Malakand Fort is a prominent colonial-era fortification built by the British in the late 19th century to control the Malakand Pass. It played a significant role during the Malakand Campaign of 1897.
safetyNotes: Photography near military sections restricted.

name: Kheshgi Fort
description: Kheshgi Fort is an old defensive structure near the Kabul River, historically used by local tribes and later the British. It stands as a symbol of local heritage and tribal defense architecture.
safetyNotes: Avoid climbing unsafe walls; no public facilities nearby.

name: Mansehra Rock Edicts
description: The Mansehra Rock Edicts are ancient inscriptions carved by Emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BCE. These edicts, written in Kharosthi script, spread the message of Buddhism and peace.
safetyNotes: Avoid touching inscriptions; site protected by Department of Archaeology.

name: Pir Baba Shrine (Zirat Pir Baba)
description: Pir Baba (Syed Ali Ghawth Shah Tirmizi) is a widely venerated Sufi saint; his shrine (ziarat) in Buner is an important pilgrimage and cultural site for the region.It faces disaster like flood now in 2025
hotelsNearby: Swat Continental Hotel (Mingora, nearest large hotel)
localCuisine: Pashtun specialities: chapli kebab, rice dishes
restaurantsNearby: Local dhabas and guest-house eateries in Daggar/Buner
roadCondition: Mostly paved highways; local hilly approach roads with curves
safetyNotes: Respect shrine etiquette; avoid large gatherings during unstable weather; carry water

name: Ziarat Kaka Sahib (Kaka Sahib Shrine)
description: Ziarat Kaka Sahib is the site of the shrine of the renowned Sufi saint Kaka Sahib (Kastir Gul). The shrine sits in a rugged hill area south of Nowshera city and is frequently visited by pilgrims from across Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
hotelsNearby: Local guest houses in Nowshera city
nearbyAttractions: Qissa Khwani-style bazaars in nearby Peshawar
roadCondition: Good paved roads to Nowshera; short hilly approach
safetyNotes: Commonly visited; be respectful during religious ceremonies

name: Sheikh Mali (Sheikh Malli Baba) Shrine
description: Sheikh Mali (Sheikh Malli) is remembered in local Yousafzai Pashtun history  his tomb / shrine in Swat (commonly referenced near Qamber/Qambar) is visited by locals and historians interested in Pashtun tribal history.
roadCondition: Good highway to Mingora; local approach roads vary
safetyNotes: Check local accessibility; some rural shrines have limited facilities

name: Panjpir Shrine / Panj Pir area
description: Panj Pir (literally 'Five Pirs') is a town and spiritual area in Swabi associated with several Sufi saints; the Panj Pir hill and local shrines/dargahs draw visitors and students (seminaries) from across the region.
hotelsNearby: Hotels at Swabi Interchange / M1 motorway hotels

nearestAirport.name: Islamabad International Airport (ISB) or Bacha Khan Int. (PEW) depending on route

roadCondition: Good motorway/highway access; local rural roads to shrines
safetyNotes: Respect local religious customs; the region has active seminaries  avoid political discussions

name: Haji Baba (local shrine, Mardan area)
description: A local shrine commonly referred to as 'Haji Baba' (multiple local shrines exist in Mardan district). This entry refers to the commonly visited small dargah(s) in the Mardan area  a typical local religious site visited by residents.
hotelsNearby: Local guest houses / small hotels in Mardan
restaurantsNearby: Local Mardan restaurants (Bacha Khan Chowk area)
roadCondition: Good main roads; local lanes vary
safetyNotes: Local shrines vary in facilities  carry water and respect visiting hours

name: Tarbela Dam
description: Tarbela Dam, located on the Indus River in Haripur District, is one of the worlds largest earth-filled dams. It provides hydroelectric power, irrigation water, and scenic lake views popular for boating and picnicking.
busStationsFromPeshawar: Peshawar  Haripur / Tarbela bus routes via M1M15 motorway
requiredDocuments: Special entry permit for restricted dam zones
entryFeePermits: Restricted access in dam zone; visitor pass required for certain areas
roadCondition: Good highway and access road; security checks at main gates
safetyNotes: Follow WAPDA safety guidelines; restricted photography near control structures

name: Khanpur Dam
description: Khanpur Dam on the Haro River near Haripur is a major tourist destination famous for its turquoise water, water sports, and scenic hills. It supplies water to Islamabad and Rawalpindi.
entryFeePermits: Entry ticket for lake activities required
roadCondition: Paved with some narrow turns; tourist parking available
safetyNotes: Wear life jackets during water sports; avoid deep areas without guide

name: Warsak Dam
description: Warsak Dam is located on the Kabul River, about 20 km northwest of Peshawar. It was built in the 1960s with Canadian assistance and provides electricity and irrigation water to the region.
safetyNotes: Follow dam security protocols; photography limited near control gates

name: Dargai Dam
description: Dargai Dam, located in Malakand District, is a small hydroelectric power project that also serves as a scenic site surrounded by hills and greenery. Its one of the oldest operational dams in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
requiredDocuments: CNIC required for entry near dam zone
entryFeePermits: Restricted zone  permission may be required
roadCondition: Mostly paved; hilly curves near approach
safetyNotes: Avoid restricted areas; maintain distance from spillway zones

name: Kund Park
description: Kund Park is a scenic wildlife and recreation park located at the confluence of the Kabul and Indus Rivers in Nowshera District. It offers boating, picnicking, and natural river views.
roadCondition: Good paved road up to the park entrance
safetyNotes: Stay away from deep river edges; boating with life jackets recommended.

name: Khanpur Lake
description: Khanpur Lake is a man-made reservoir on the Haro River near Khanpur town. It is famous for water sports, scenic views, and weekend getaways from Islamabad and Peshawar.
roadCondition: Excellent paved roads from Haripur and Islamabad
safetyNotes: Follow water safety instructions; avoid swimming alone.

name: Tanda Dam
description: Tanda Dam is a beautiful reservoir located near Kohat, known for its blue water, boating facilities, and picnic areas. It also serves as a major water supply for the region.
roadCondition: Good paved road with minor rough patches near the dam
safetyNotes: Avoid deep water zones; supervision required for children.

name: Baran Dam
description: Baran Dam, located near Bannu, is an irrigation and water supply project surrounded by hills and greenery. Its a peaceful site for fishing, photography, and picnics.
safetyNotes: Best to visit during day; no lifeguards available.

name: Kohat Toi River
description: The Kohat Toi River flows through Kohat Valley, providing water for irrigation and scenic beauty to the surrounding landscape. Its a peaceful site for picnics and photography.
safetyNotes: Avoid during high rainfall due to rising water levels.

name: Kohat Tunnel
description: Kohat Tunnel, also known as the Pak-Japan Friendship Tunnel, connects Kohat with Peshawar through the Khigana Hills. Its a vital transportation route and an engineering landmark.
safetyNotes: Follow speed limits; tunnel lighting may dim at night.

name: Khushal Garh Bridge
description: The Khushal Garh Bridge spans the Indus River and connects Khyber Pakhtunkhwa with Punjab. It offers stunning river views and serves as an important transportation link.
safetyNotes: Be cautious when stopping on bridge for photos.

name: Karak Salt Mines
description: The Karak Salt Mines are known for their vast deposits of high-quality rock salt. The area is surrounded by rugged hills and attracts geology and nature enthusiasts.
safetyNotes: Avoid entering deep mine areas without a guide.

name: Takht-e-Nusrati Hills
description: Takht-e-Nusrati Hills are known for their scenic beauty and mineral-rich formations. The area offers panoramic views and is ideal for off-road exploration.
safetyNotes: Use off-road vehicle for higher elevations.

name: Lachi Picnic Spot
description: Lachi Picnic Spot is a relaxing location near Kohat, known for its green hills and fresh air. Families often visit for day trips and outdoor activities.
safetyNotes: Carry water and sun protection.

name: Sheen Ghar Mountains
description: Sheen Ghar Mountains are located near Bannu, known for their blueish hue and scenic ridges. The site is popular for off-road drives and local exploration.
safetyNotes: Avoid visiting during heavy rain.

name: Kurram River
description: The Kurram River flows through the Bannu region, providing scenic beauty, fertile plains, and opportunities for fishing and boating.
safetyNotes: Avoid swimming; strong currents.

name: Sheikh Badin Hills
description: Sheikh Badin Hills, located at the junction of Lakki Marwat and D.I. Khan, is a serene hill station known for its cool weather, panoramic views, and British-era colonial ruins.
roadCondition: Hilly and winding roads; accessible by 4x4
safetyNotes: Steep terrain; drive carefully on narrow paths.

name: Pezu Mountains
description: Pezu Mountains lie between D.I. Khan and Lakki Marwat, offering rugged landscapes and scenic drives. The range is popular among hikers and nature photographers.
safetyNotes: Take extra fuel and water; limited facilities.

name: Zhob River Confluence
description: The Zhob River Confluence marks where the Zhob River meets the Gomal River, forming a scenic and ecologically rich spot ideal for nature observation and photography.
roadCondition: Paved up to access point; dirt track near confluence
safetyNotes: Avoid during monsoon due to river flooding.

name: Gomal River Picnic Point
description: Located near the Gomal River, this picnic point is a peaceful retreat offering boating, fishing, and scenic sunset views over the water.
roadCondition: Good paved road up to site
safetyNotes: Avoid swimming in deep water; strong currents.

name: Tirah Valley
description: Tirah Valley, located in the Khyber District near the Pak-Afghan border, is a breathtaking highland known for its forests, streams, and rich tribal heritage. Its one of Khyber Pakhtunkhwas most scenic yet less explored valleys.
safetyNotes: Check local travel advisories; remote terrain.

name: Orakzai Valley
description: Orakzai Valley is known for its green meadows, orchards, and cool climate. The valley also holds historical significance with ancient forts and tribal heritage.
safetyNotes: Carry warm clothing; area gets cold at night.

name: Parachinar
description: Parachinar, the capital of Kurram District, lies near the Afghan border and is known for its pleasant weather, orchards, and scenic mountain backdrop. Its often called the 'Mini Kashmir of Pakistan' for its natural charm.
safetyNotes: Check local advisories before travel.

name: Spin Ghar Range
description: The Spin Ghar (White Mountains) Range forms a stunning natural barrier between Pakistan and Afghanistan. Known for snow-capped peaks, pine forests, and alpine meadows, its ideal for adventure tourism and photography.
safetyNotes: Cold climate year-round; carry warm clothing.

name: Shawal Valley
description: Shawal Valley is one of North Waziristans most scenic and secluded valleys, surrounded by pine-clad hills and mountain streams. It is famous for its peaceful ambiance and pristine wilderness.
roadCondition: Mountain roads; rough tracks in parts
safetyNotes: Remote area; travel with local guide.

name: Razmak Valley
description: Razmak Valley, known as the 'Switzerland of Waziristan', is famed for its lush green meadows, cool weather, and pine forests. It was once a British era hill station and remains a peaceful summer retreat.
safetyNotes: Cool temperatures; carry warm clothes.

name: Ladha Valley
description: Ladha Valley is a high-altitude region in South Waziristan known for its rugged beauty and pine-covered slopes. It offers panoramic views, cool weather, and a peaceful natural atmosphere.
safetyNotes: Remote area; travel in groups recommended.

name: Ziarat Tirah Maidan
description: Ziarat Tirah Maidan is a vast green plateau in the Tirah region of Khyber District. Known for its lush meadows, springs, and spiritual significance, it attracts nature lovers and pilgrims alike.
safetyNotes: Best visited with local guide; remote area.

name: Takht-e-Sulaiman (Sulaiman Mountains)
description: Takht-e-Sulaiman, also known as the Throne of Solomon, is a sacred mountain peak located on the border between Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan. It holds great historical and spiritual significance, offering breathtaking panoramic views of the Sulaiman Range and surrounding valleys.
roadCondition: Mountain tracks, partially unpaved; suitable for 4x4
safetyNotes: Remote area; carry sufficient water and fuel. Avoid visiting during heavy rains.

name: Samanah Top
description: Samanah Top is a beautiful viewpoint located near the PakistanAfghanistan border in Hangu District. Surrounded by pine-covered hills and offering stunning sunsets, its a peaceful destination for hiking and nature enthusiasts.
roadCondition: Paved but steep roads; accessible by car and SUV
safetyNotes: Avoid visiting at night; border area, check local security advisories.

name: Murree
description: Not in kpk, But Murree is a famous hill station located in the Pir Panjal Range of the Rawalpindi District, Punjab. Though not in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, it is one of Pakistans most visited mountain resorts. Murree offers lush green hills, pine forests, cool weather, and panoramic views of the surrounding valleys, making it an ideal retreat for families and tourists.
bestTimeToVisit: April to October for greenery; December to February for snowfall
localCuisine: Makki di Roti & Sarson da Saag
roadCondition: Well-paved mountain roads; busy during peak season
safetyNotes: Drive carefully on steep roads; heavy traffic during holidays and snowfall season.

name: Neelum Valley
description: not in kpk, But Neelum Valley is a paradise-like destination in Azad Jammu & Kashmir, filled with pine forests, snow-capped peaks, crystal-clear rivers, and breathtaking villages. Stretching along the Neelum River, its one of the most beautiful and accessible valleys in the region.
roadCondition: Partially paved; rough patches beyond Keran; 4x4 recommended.
safetyNotes: Mobile signals limited; check weather before travel.

name: Ratti Gali Lake
description: Ratti Gali Lake is a stunning glacial lake located at 3,683 meters in Neelum Valley. Surrounded by snowy peaks and lush meadows, this lake is accessible only by a scenic jeep track followed by a short hike  a perfect spot for adventurers and photographers.
roadCondition: Steep and unpaved; jeep access only.
safetyNotes: Weather changes quickly; pack warm gear.

name: Rawalakot
description: Rawalakot, also called the Pearl Valley, is a beautiful hill town surrounded by green hills and forests. It serves as a comfortable base for exploring Banjosa Lake, Toli Pir, and other AJK attractions, with modern hotels and peaceful scenery.
roadCondition: Good condition; occasional landslides during monsoon.
safetyNotes: Check road conditions in rainy season.

name: Toli Pir
description: Toli Pir is a popular hilltop viewpoint near Rawalakot offering panoramic views of Poonch Valley and the surrounding mountains. Its famous for its green meadows, hiking trails, and peaceful picnic spots.
roadCondition: Curvy and steep; accessible by car.
safetyNotes: Avoid after sunset due to fog and low visibility.

name: Leepa Valley
description: Leepa Valley is known as the 'Heaven of Kashmir' with its traditional wooden houses, lush fields, and snow-covered peaks. Close to the Line of Control, its a peaceful and stunning area showcasing authentic Kashmiri lifestyle and natural beauty.
safetyNotes: Check local advisories; avoid during heavy rain.

name: Banjosa Lake
description: Banjosa Lake is a charming man-made lake surrounded by pine forests near Rawalakot. Its calm waters, cool climate, and picnic areas make it one of the most family-friendly spots in Azad Kashmir.
safetyNotes: Can get crowded on weekends; maintain cleanliness.

name: Arang Kel
description: Arang Kel is a magical hilltop village above Kel in Neelum Valley, often called the 'Mini Switzerland of Pakistan.' Surrounded by clouds, forests, and wooden cottages, its accessible by a scenic chairlift and short trek.
roadCondition: Steep jeep track; then 1-hour hike from chairlift station.
safetyNotes: Weather can turn cloudy quickly; bring warm clothing.

name: Skardu
description: Skardu is the gateway to some of the worlds highest peaks, including K2 and Nanga Parbat. Located in GilgitBaltistan, this stunning valley lies along the Indus River, surrounded by snow-covered mountains, turquoise lakes, and vast deserts like Katpana. Though not part of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Skardu is one of Pakistans most breathtaking destinations for trekkers, nature lovers, and adventure seekers.
bestTimeToVisit: April to October (for hiking and sightseeing); December to February (for snow lovers)
travelTime: 14 hours (by road); 1 hour (by air from Islamabad)
roadCondition: Mostly paved; rough patches near mountain passes; well-maintained highway access from Gilgit and Islamabad.
safetyNotes: Weather can change quickly; check flight and road conditions. Altitude sickness possible at high points.

name: Hunza Valley
description: Hunza Valley is one of Pakistans most iconic and beautiful mountain destinations, located along the Karakoram Highway in GilgitBaltistan. Surrounded by snow-capped peaks such as Rakaposhi and Ultar Sar, Hunza offers breathtaking views, ancient forts, vibrant local culture, and warm hospitality. Though not in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, it remains a must-visit area for tourists exploring northern Pakistan.
bestTimeToVisit: April to October (for clear views and mild weather)
roadCondition: Excellent condition along Karakoram Highway; occasional landslides during monsoon.
safetyNotes: Safe for tourists; warm hospitality of locals. Carry warm clothes; nights can be cold even in summer.
